Description: Hollow terracotta figure of Harpokrates shown in Roman style, naked and standing, with finger to mouth, his head tilted to his right. The head is shaven except for a side-lock, and he wears a Double Crown flanked by lotus buds. An overflowing cornucopia is carried in the crook of his left arm. Back plain. The feet are lost and the break smoothed in recent times; a hole is bored underneath for a modern mount. Two-piece mould. Micaceous orange-brown Nile silt with a red-brown surface. Traces of a thickly applied white dressing on the front.
Curator's comments: Terracotta IV Purchased. Gustav Moustaki Collection. Ptolemaic, probably first century BC. Comparanda: Close, probably same mould-series: Kaufmann 1913: fig. 28:8. Near: Ballet 1995: pl. xxvii:2; Breccia 1930: no. 257, from the Hadra cemetery, Alexandria; Fischer 1994: no. 595, dated first half of first century AD. Bibliog: Vassilika 1994: 180, no. 30.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3043)
